page.title: 07VIKING WAY - King Lud's area
page.content: The Viking Way is a long distance footpath from the Humber Bridge, through the Lincolnshire Wolds,around the edge of the Fens, to the Vale of Belvoir and Rutland. The footpath crosses the eastern side of this area following Sewstern Lane (or The Drift) which forms the boundary between Leicestershire and Lincolnshire. This trackway may date from the Bronze Age and was once the main route from the Trent to Stamford where it joined Ermine Street, the main road to London from the north. More direct routes eventually made the road redundant and it was only used by farmers to take their sheep and cattle to market. It is now used mainly by hikers. The age of the roadway and the fact that it has not been farmed or chemically treated has resulted in it being made an SSSI.
